Electronics¶

class components.electronics.electronics.Electronics(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

This class will instantiate the flight controller and speed_controller(s) and place them on top of one another.

Returns:ParaPy Geometry of the electronics
amp_req[source]¶

This is the required amperage for the engine(s).

Returns:Complete Amp draw from the engine(s) in SI Amps
Return type:float
box_length[source]¶

This returns the length of the flight controller box for calculations.

Returns:Flight Controller Length
Return type:float
center_of_gravity[source]¶

This attribute finds the center of gravities of the separate ESCs, then finds the combined C.G.

Returns:ParaPy Point
Return type:Point
component_type[source]¶

This attribute names the component ‘electronics’ for electronics.

Returns:String with electronics component name
Return type:str
elec_joiner[source]¶

This joins the ESC’s together through a series of Fuse operations to be able to present a single internal_shape required for the fuselage frame sizing.

Returns:ParaPy Fused Boxes
Return type:Fused
flight_controller[source]¶

This an instantiation of the flight controller. It takes only the position input.

Returns:Flight controller geometry
Return type:TranslatedShape
internal_shape[source]¶

This is creating a box for the fuselage frames. This is used to get around ParaPy errors.

Returns:Speed Controller(s) bounded box
Return type:ScaledShape
number_engines[source]¶

This is used to determine the number of engines from the input motor_in.

Returns:Number of Engines
Return type:int
speed_controller[source]¶

This an instantiation of the speed controller class. It requires the amp draw and the number of engines and position as input.

Returns:Speed Controller(s) Geometry
Return type:Box
weight[source]¶

Total mass of the electronics components

Returns:Mass in SI kilograms
Return type:float
class components.electronics.flightcontroller.FlightController(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

This class will create the Navio2 flight controller geometry.

Returns:ParaPy Geometry of the flight computer
center_of_gravity[source]¶

This attribute returns the COG of the flight controller.

Returns:ParaPy Point
Return type:ParaPy Point
component_type[source]¶

This attribute names the component ‘flightcontroller’ for flight controller.

Returns:String with flightcontroller’s component name
Return type:str
flight_controller_power[source]¶

This attribute estimates the Navio2 flight computer power. It is found by multiplying the average voltage (5V), by the average current (150mA). Source: https://emlid.com/navio/

Returns:Flight Computer Power
Return type:float
flightcontroller_offset[source]¶

This creates the geometry of the flight controller. FOR BOX FUNCTION: Width is x direction, length is y direction, height is z direction.

Returns:ParaPy Flight Controller Geometry
Return type:Box
h_navio[source]¶

The flight controller height is to be oriented parallel with the y axis. This height was assumed from their figure.

Returns:ParaPy Flight Controller height
Return type:float
internal_shape[source]¶

This obtains a bounding box of the flight controller to size the fuselage frames.

Returns:Navio2 Shape
Return type:ScaledShape
l_navio[source]¶
The 65mm length of the Flight Computer is the longest dimension and is to be oriented parallel with the x
axis. Dimensions are at https://emlid.com/navio/
Returns:ParaPy Flight Controller Length
Return type:float
label[source]¶

This labels the flight controller ‘Avionics’

Returns:Avionics Label
Return type:str
solid[source]¶

This shifts the shape to the correct place with respect to the local axis system.

Returns:ParaPy Flight Controller Geometry
Return type:TranslatedShape
w_navio[source]¶

The 55mm width is to be oriented parallel with the y axis.

Returns:ParaPy Flight Controller Width
Return type:float
weight[source]¶

The mass of the Navio2 flight computer is 23 grams.

Returns:Navio2 Mass
Return type:float
class components.electronics.speedcontroller.SpeedController(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

This class will create the electronic speed controllers for the UAV. This is done based on the number of engines (each requires its own ESC), and the engine choice (determines amp rating). This will return a number of ESCs stacked vertically, and the COG displayed at the end is the combined COG of all ESCs. The ESC is sized (mass and volume) my linear regression of reference ESC’s found on HobbyKing.

Returns:ParaPy Geometry of the ESC(s)
amp_range[source]¶

This attribute contains the amp rating for ESCs found on hobbyking covering our spectrum of motor options in our motor database that will be used for regression.

Returns:List of ECC amperage’s in SI Amps
Return type:list
center_of_gravity[source]¶

This attribute finds the center of gravities of the separate ESCs, then finds the combined C.G.

Returns:ParaPy Point
Return type:Point
component_type[source]¶

This attribute names the component ‘speedcontroller’ for speedcontroller.

Returns:String with speedcontroller’s component name
Return type:str
esc_dims[source]¶

This attribute creates the speed controller dimensions, with the same cross-section as the flight computer. Their height can change, according to the required size.

Returns:ESC Dimensions
Return type:List
esc_joiner[source]¶

This joins the ESC’s together through a series of Fuse operations to be able to present a single internal_shape required for the fuselage frame sizing.

Returns:ParaPy Fused Boxes
Return type:Fused
esc_size[source]¶

This attribute estimates the esc size from the linear regression of the found ESC amperage’s and corresponding volumes. If there are more than one engine, there will be more than one ESC.

Returns:Total ESC weight
Return type:float
esc_size_plot[source]¶

This attribute creates a plot of the ESC volume vs. continuous amperage. It is save in the path ‘user/plots’

Returns:Plot of ESC volume vs. continuous amperage
Return type:Plot
esc_weight[source]¶

This attribute estimates the esc weight from the linear regression of the found ESC amperage’s and corresponding weights. If there are more than one motor, multiple ESCs are used and the complete weight is calculated here

Returns:Total ESC weight
Return type:float
esc_weight_plot[source]¶

This attribute creates a plot of the ESC weight vs. continuous amperage. It is saved in the path ‘user/plots’.

Returns:Plot of ESC weight vs. Amperage
Return type:Plot
first_esc_pos[source]¶

This is the first position of the bottom ESC, which is to be placed on top of the flight computer

Returns:First ESC Position
Return type:Position
h_navio[source]¶

The flight controller height is to be oriented parallel with the y axis. This height was assumed from their figure.

Returns:ParaPy Flight Controller height
Return type:float
internal_shape[source]¶

This is creating a box for the fuselage frames. This is used to get around ParaPy errors.

Returns:Speed Controller(s) bounded box
Return type:ScaledShape
l_navio[source]¶
The 65mm length of the Flight Computer is the longest dimension and is to be oriented parallel with the x
axis. Dimensions are at https://emlid.com/navio/
Returns:ParaPy Flight Controller Length
Return type:float
label[source]¶

This labels the speed controller ‘Speed Controller’

Returns:Navio2 Mass
Return type:float
speed_controllers[source]¶

This creates the speed controller(s). If there are multiple, they are positioned relative to one another.

Returns:ESC Geometries
Return type:Box
volume_range[source]¶

This attribute contains the corresponding volumes of the ESCs found on hobbyking

Returns:List of ECS Volumes in SI m^3
Return type:list
w_navio[source]¶

The 55mm width is to be oriented parallel with the y axis.

Returns:ParaPy Flight Controller Width
Return type:float
weight[source]¶

The mass of the speed controller(s)

Returns:Speed Controller(s) Mass
Return type:float
weight_range[source]¶

This attribute contains the corresponding weights of the ESCs found on hobbyking

Returns:List of ECS Weights in SI kg
Return type:list
